com.foreach.across.modules.filemanager.services

Class AbstractExpiringFileRepository<T extends ExpiringFileResource>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.foreach.across.modules.filemanager.services.AbstractFileRepository
      • com.foreach.across.modules.filemanager.services.AbstractExpiringFileRepository<T>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    FileManagerAware, FileRepository
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    CachingFileRepository, ExpiringFileRepository

    public abstract class AbstractExpiringFileRepository<T extends ExpiringFileResource>
extends AbstractFileRepository
    Base class for a file repository which tracks its file resources and expires them according to a specific expirationStrategy. The actual meaning of expiration depends on the particular implementation.

    A target repository is configured which delivers the original file resource that should be adapted into an ExpiringFileResource. The expiring repository takes the identity of the target repository, developers should only register the expiring repository.

    This repository keeps an LRU type map of known file descriptors. The maximum number of resources to track can be configured. Once this maximum is exceeded, the oldest file resource will be evicted; after which point it will be fetched again from the target repository. If a resource expires when evicted depends on the expireOnEvict value.

    In the base implementation folder resources do not expire but only the file resources they return are converted to expiring resources. The actual folder actions are executed directly on the target folder resource. This means that folder executions (for example listing of files) can quickly cause evictions if maxItemsToTrack is too low as every file returned will be wrapped as an expiring file resource.

    Since:
    1.4.0
    Author:
    Arne Vandamme
    See Also:
    ExpiringFileRepository, CachingFileRepository

      • createFileResource

        public T createFileResource(boolean allocateImmediately)
        Description copied from interface: FileRepository
        Create a new file resource in the repository and optionally allocate it immediately. The resource returned is guaranteed not to exist before the call to this method, and can normally be written to after. The call to Resource.exists() should return true if parameter allocateImmediately was true.

        Allocating the file usually creates an empty physical file or the equivalent for the underlying storage engine.

        Specified by:
        createFileResource in interface FileRepository
        Overrides:
        createFileResource in class AbstractFileRepository
        Parameters:
        allocateImmediately - true if
        Returns:
        FileResource instance.

      • getFileResource

        public T getFileResource(FileDescriptor descriptor)
        Description copied from interface: FileRepository
        Returns the FileResource represented by the descriptor. Should never be null. An IllegalArgumentException will be thrown if the descriptor does not match the repository or is illegal in any way.

        Note that this does not mean that the actual file resource exists. Only a call to Resource.exists() would verify that. The return value simply implies that a resource matching that descriptor could exist or be created.

        Specified by:
        getFileResource in interface FileRepository
        Overrides:
        getFileResource in class AbstractFileRepository
        Parameters:
        descriptor - to get the file resource for
        Returns:
        file resource

      • createFileResource

        public T createFileResource(File originalFile,
                            boolean deleteOriginal)
                     throws IOException
        Description copied from interface: FileRepository
        Create a new file in the repository. This allocates the file resource and copies the data of the file parameter.

        If parameter deleteOriginal is true, the original file will be deleted once the resource has been created. This is useful when moving temporary files.

        By default the extension of the original file will be added to the file descriptor, so it can more easily be used for mime type detection.

        Parameters:
        originalFile - data to copy into the resource
        deleteOriginal - true if the original file should be deleted when done
        Returns:
        FileResource instance.
        Throws:
        IOException

      • createFileResource

        public T createFileResource(InputStream inputStream)
                     throws IOException
        Description copied from interface: FileRepository
        Create a new file in the repository. This allocates the file resource and copies the data represented by the inputStream parameter. It is the responsibility of the caller to correctly close the input stream when done.

        By default this does the same as FileRepository.createFileResource() followed by a call to FileResource.copyFrom(InputStream).

        Parameters:
        inputStream - data to copy into the resource
        Returns:
        FileResource instance
        Throws:
        IOException

      • createFileResource

        public T createFileResource()
        Description copied from interface: FileRepository
        Create a new file resource in the repository. The resource returned is guaranteed not to exist before the call to this method, and can normally be written to (can effectively be created).

        This does not allocate the physical storage for the actual file, that should only happen when actual data is written to the file resource. If you want to create a new file resource and immediately allocate it, use FileRepository.createFileResource(boolean) instead.

        This method usually does the same as calling createFileResource(false).

        Returns:
        FileResource instance.

      • shutdown

        @PreDestroy
public void shutdown()
        Shutdown the repository. Depending on the value of expireOnShutdown the tracked resources will be expired.

      • expireTrackedItems

        public static void expireTrackedItems(@NonNull
                                      @NonNull FileRepositoryRegistry fileRepositoryRegistry)
        Run the expiration (removal of stale items) on all AbstractExpiringFileRepository implementations. Detects all implementations of AbstractExpiringFileRepository in the FileRepositoryRegistry and executes expireTrackedItems().
        Parameters:
        fileRepositoryRegistry - that holds the repositories
        See Also:
        FileRepositoryRegistry

      • timeBasedExpirationStrategy

        public static Function<ExpiringFileResource,Boolean> timeBasedExpirationStrategy(long maxUnusedDuration,
                                                                                 long maxAge)
        Configures a time-based expiration function which expires resources if they have not been accessed for longer than maxUnusedDuration or if their creation time was longer than maxAge ago. Whichever condition matches.

        Both time durations are in milliseconds. The reference for access time is ExpiringFileResource.getLastAccessTime(), the reference for age is ExpiringFileResource.getCreationTime().

        Specifying zero or less will skip that condition.

        Parameters:
        maxUnusedDuration - maximum number of milliseconds that is allowed since last access time
        maxAge - maximum number of milliseconds that is allowed since cache has been created
        Returns:
        expiration function

      • getTargetFileRepository

        public FileRepository getTargetFileRepository()
        The target repository this implementation wraps.

      • isExpireOnShutdown

        public boolean isExpireOnShutdown()
        True if resources should be expired when the file repository is destroyed.

      • isExpireOnEvict

        public boolean isExpireOnEvict()
        True if resources should be expired when they are evicted.

      • getMaxItemsToTrack

        public int getMaxItemsToTrack()
        Maximum number of file resources to track. Past this number the least recently fetched file descriptor will be evicted. Depending on expireOnEvict this means the actual resource will be expired immediately.

      • getExpirationStrategy

        public Function<ExpiringFileResource,Boolean> getExpirationStrategy()
        Function which returns true if a file resource should be expired.
